_exec_summary.SummaryText:
BGC Dairy is a milk, orange juice, and lemonade processing plant owned and operated by Brookshire Grocery Company under the Brookshire's and Value Time labels in Tyler, Texas. BGC Dairy plant also copacks for several organic and conventional labels as well. BGC Dairy uses Anhydrous Ammonia to keep products at federal mandated temperature levels and there is approximately 13,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia on site. BGC Dairy has not had a reportable release of Anhydrous Ammonia in more than thirty years. The entire facility is located behind an eight-foot security fence with authorized personnel access only to and from premises. Armed security personnel guard the entire facility, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. BGC manufacturing maintenance department has over 100 years of combined experience with Anhydrous Ammonia.

 Maintenance personnel responsible for the ammonia system are trained every year in the proper technique of wearing emergency response equipment such as SCBA, Ammonia Respirators, Level A Suits, and other required PPE In Accordance With (IAW) OSHA 1910.134. BGC Dairy and Brookshire Grocery Company maintain close ties with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), Tyler Fire Department, and their Hazmat Team. Annually BGC Dairy conducts tours for these organizations to maintain familiarity with the facility. The Tyler Fire Department and their Hazmat Team have both recognized the experience that BGC Dairy personnel have in respect to Anhydrous Ammonia response and have requested that the Hazmat Team backup BGC Dairy personnel in the event of an ammonia release. In addition, all on site partners receive training and conduct rehearsals in emergency evacuation quarterly. All new partners receive training in emergency evacuation and ammonia awareness during the new partner orientation process.

BGC Dairy's ammonia equipment is in an enclosed room that vents to the atmosphere. All piping is routed to the roof so that if there is a Pressure Release Valve

(PRV) discharge, the release will be outdoors. All piping from our pressure relief valves are tied into main headers that have been routed to the roof and placed an additional twenty feet in the air IAW ANSI/IIAR 2 1999 7.3.2. An "Emergency Anhydrous Ammonia Control Box" is located outside the building, but within our facility, that would allow authorized Personnel to shut down the system in the event of a major release. BGC Dairy has implemented and continues to conduct an aggressive and preventative maintenance program, IAW IIAR Bulletin 110, to ensure that all hazards are addressed to reduce the risk of an Anhydrous Ammonia release.

In the event of a suspected release of Anhydrous Ammonia, BGC Dairy has a Spill Prevention Control and Contermeasures Plan, and Emergency Response Contingency Plan in place. This plan receives annual updates, or when deemed necessary by Management or the Environmental Health and Safety Coordinator. The plan is designed to protect our partners and our community. BGC Dairy, Supervision, Security, LEPC, Tyler Fire Department, and their Hazmat Team have access to the Emergency Response Contingency Plan. This plan consists of an emergency notification call down list containing 24 hour contact numbers for all trained responders, the duties for Ammonia Specialist/Responders, contact information for the LEPC, SERC, NRC, TCEQ, and a  MSDS  for Anhydrous Ammonia.

BGC Dairy is planning several changes to improve safety. In addition to our annual training requirements, BGC Dairy will also conduct annual training. Another change to policy is the security guards; they will receive advanced training from an external source in hazmat response. Cross training of maintenance personnel, responsible for the ammonia, will continue between the facilities. With these changes to improve safety and continuing good engineering practices, BGC Dairy will continue to be a safe facility.
